body.name: The Paris Apartment: A Novel
body.description: THE #1 NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER“Told in rotating points of view, this Tilt-A-Whirl of a novel brims with jangly tension – an undeniably engrossing guessing game.” — Vogue"[A] clever, cliff-hanger-filled thriller." — PeopleFrom the New York Times bestselling author of The Guest List comes a new locked room mystery, set in a Paris apartment building in which every resident has something to hide…Jess needs a fresh start. She’s broke and alone, and she’s just left her job under less than ideal circumstances. Her half-brother Ben didn’t sound thrilled when she asked if she could crash with him for a bit, but he didn’t say no, and surely everything will look better from Paris. Only when she shows up – to find a very nice apartment, could Ben really have afforded this? – he’s not there.The longer Ben stays missing, the more Jess starts to dig into her brother’s situation, and the more questions she has. Ben’s neighbors are an eclectic bunch, and not particularly friendly. Jess may have come to Paris to escape her past, but it’s starting to look like it’s Ben’s future that’s in question.The socialite – The nice guy – The alcoholic – The girl on the verge – The conciergeEveryone's a neighbor. Everyone's a suspect. And everyone knows something they’re not telling. Read more

productInformation.name: Narrator
productInformation.value: Clare Corbett, Daphne Kouma, Julia Winwood, Sope Dirisu, Sofia Zervudachi, Charlie Anson

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I loved it. This was my first book I read of hers. I really enjoyed the audio and writing style of the book. Each chapter started in 1st person making it easier to read all the way through. It was such a great book, characters are well connected, the plot of discovering something you shouldn’t have known. The whole family living in this one apartment, the mystery and secrets each of the me have. How they all love or fell for the main male character. I can’t wait to read other books from her .

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Another great thriller from Lucy Foley
reviews.reviewText: I had been wanting to read this book for a long time. Now that I've moved to Paris, I figured "why not?" I'm a big fan of Lucy Foley's writing style and have read some of her other thrillers. This one felt subpar compared to The Guest List, but was still enjoyable. Lucy always does a great job of foreshadowing just enough that you're able to make subtle guesses, yet still keeps you wondering what's actually going on. You can also learn some French curse words as well ;)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Not My Cuppa
reviews.reviewText: I love good mysteries, detective stories, and thrillers. I read a lot of them and have several favorite authors. I put a high value on creative and intelligent writing. Unfortunately, I did not find this book to be highly creative or intelligent.I constantly found myself thinking that the author was trying too hard. Too hard to be clever, surprising, and mysterious and failing on all counts. I thought it seemed a bit childish, as if written by a young person eager to impress.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great Whodunnit! Hard to put down.
reviews.reviewText: This was my first Lucy Foley mystery. Her writing style is a great style, each chapter stated in the first person, but switching back and forth, giving you a fascinating perspective as you keep seeing what happened through the perspective of all the main characters. And, the story is delightful murder mystery, our heroine, Jess, is the gutsy, nosy, bold, sister of the missing person, who refuses to back off. Jess is written so well. Flawed and filled with shortcomings, unsure of exactly what is going on, but street smart and tenacious as a bloodhound on the scent. Foley also gives some very smart twists in the story that also added a little more believability in terms of motives and how the crime unfolded. After the story Lucy Foley gives you incite into what inspired this story, and I really enjoyed reading that as well, as you could definitely see the influences of Alfred Hitchcock, Georges Simenon, and others.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars engaging, quick read
reviews.reviewText: Loved the twists and turns with this story. I had theories about what was happening, and they were all wrong. I love when that happens.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I could not stop reading! All the twists and turns and surprises!It was definitely an awesome read!Will recommend.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Enjoyable light reading
reviews.reviewText: Book club choice. Wanted to keep on reading

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2022
reviews.reviewText: Told in short chapters through multiple POVs, in the latest Lucy Foley’s thriller we follow Jess Hadley, a bartender at the Copacabana bar in Brighton, England, who finds herself in a difficult situation in which she needs to leave everything behind. So she decides to go to Paris to visit her half-brother Ben.While Jess is on her way, her brother leaves her a message giving her instructions on how to proceed when she gets into the building. But when Jess finally arrives, Ben is nowhere to be found. His apartment is much more she could have imagined. How Ben could afford such a fancy apartment being a freelance journalist? He also left his wallet behind and Jess decides to ask around his whereabouts.The reader is left in the dark for most of the story. It is impossible not to be reminded of the Hulu series Only Murders in the Building, without the podcast element, while reading this novel. Just like in the series, everyone living in this building becomes a suspect. The building holds a lot of secrets, and secret passages, and the protagonist soon realizes that things are not what they seem.The characters are well developed. Foley gives us a background story of Jess and Ben, and their different upbringing. After their mother died, the siblings were split up. Ben was adopted by a wealthy couple and had a comfortable life while Jess lived from one foster home to another. There are some unexpected twists and her writing flows. I like the author’s ability to create a creepy atmosphere.It was my first Lucy Foley and I enjoyed reading this one. I also liked how the tension was built slowly but there was nothing in this novel that really wowed me. I believe The Paris Apartment would be an enjoyable read for fans of mystery/thriller in general. It is an ok book, one that will entertain the reader without being extraordinary. Now I am curious to read more from this author.
The characters are quite interesting. Lots of mystery in what I imagine is a beautiful old building filled with secrets.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 2, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Thoroughly enjoyed reading it very complex story but really got engrossed with it couldn't put it down

Me gustó. Ultimamente leo mucho este género y parece que todos los escritores sigan un manual de instrucciones.... Agradezco a la autora su esfuerzo en escribir algo un poco original. Te mantiene en alerta, te sorprende bastante, enhorabuena a la autora otra vez.
Un livre agréable à lire et prenant
